subject: Chikamura tatematsuru (saiba Juto)
msgSnippet: Alan, You are correct. I handled that sword about 10+ yrs. ago. It was designated Juyo Token while in the possession of a U.S. collector. The sayagaki by Homma

Alan,
You are correct.
I handled that sword about 10+ yrs. ago.
It was designated Juyo Token while in the possession
of a U.S. collector. The sayagaki by Homma sensei stated
explicitly that the sword was saiba but because of it's
extreme importance as reference material was granted Juyo status.
The only other extant example being in the
Imperial Household Collection (Gyobutsu).
It was sold to a Japanese dealer who understood its importance.
P.S. It was signed Chikamura Murakami.
The Murakami was not added later, but is read as tatematsuru.

Regards,
Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

Tel. 415-751-3784

condell@...
http://www.ikkyudo.com

alan bale wrote:
> Re retempered blades getting papers, there is at least one Juyo saiba blade,
> it is signed 'Chikamura Tatematsuru', its existence proved that the famous
> Sanjo Munechika blade signed 'Munechika Murakami' was made by his pupil
> Chikamura and had the 'mune' added later. 'kami' and 'tatematsuru' being the
> same kanji.
> 


> Alan
> 
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "David Zincavage" <jdz@...>
> To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Tuesday, June 24, 2003 5:58 AM
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha
> 
> 
> : As a matter of fact, the older and wiser crowd at Cary's study group were
> tossing the term around about a Kamakura blade.  I wanted to inquire, but
> the discussion moved on, and I didn't get a chance.  I made a note of the
> term to look it up, and found Hawley's definition, which applied to a sword
> I have at home.
> :
> : I think the definition you have provided is more likely what Cary and the
> gang were talking about, though obviously odd in the case of such an old
> sword.  Thanks for the information.
> :
> :
> :   ----- Original Message -----
> :   From: Jim Gilbert
> :   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> :   Sent: Monday, June 23, 2003 8:23 PM
> :   Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha
> :
> :
> :   David,
> :   I don't think there are different forms... it's a short section of
> "unsharpened" edge just above the hamachi.  It's not unusual with gendaito,
> but is rather rare in older blades.  It is ground away as the blade is
> polished over time.
> :
> :   Very old and very good saiha swords that are otherwise intact can
> sometimes get kanteisho.
> :
> :   Hopefully someone more knowledgeable about swords can comment.
> :
> :   Jim
> :
> :
> :     Can anyone think of any publications featuring illustrations of
> different
> :     forms of ubuha?
> :
> :     Do retempered swords ever receive papers?
> :
> :
